Instance Level Variable Attribution as Break Down or SHAP Explanations

Source: R/variable_attribution.R
variable_attribution.Rd

From DALEX version 1.0 this function calls the break_down or shap functions from the iBreakDown package. Find information how to use this function here: https://pbiecek.github.io/PM_VEE/breakDown.html.

variable_attribution(explainer, new_observation, ..., type = "break_down")

variable_attribution_break_down(explainer, new_observation, ...)

variable_attribution_ibreak_down(explainer, new_observation, ...)

variable_attribution_shap(explainer, new_observation, ...)

Arguments

explainer

a model to be explained, preprocessed by the 'explain' function
new_observation

a new observarvation for which predictions need to be explained
...

other parameters that will be passed to iBreakDown::break_down
type

the type of variable attributions. Either 'shap', 'break_down' or 'ibreak_down'.

Value

An object of the class 'single_prediction_explainer'. It's a data frame with calculated average response.

References

Predictive Models: Explore, Explain, and Debug. Human-Centered Interpretable Machine Learning https://pbiecek.github.io/PM_VEE/

Examples

new_dragon <- data.frame(year_of_birth = 200,
     height = 80,
     weight = 12.5,
     scars = 0,
     number_of_lost_teeth  = 5)

dragon_lm_model4 <- lm(life_length ~ year_of_birth + height +
                                     weight + scars + number_of_lost_teeth,
                       data = dragons)
dragon_lm_explainer4 <- explain(dragon_lm_model4, data = dragons, y = dragons$year_of_birth,
                                label = "model_4v")
#> Preparation of a new explainer is initiated
#>   -> model label       :  model_4v 
#>   -> data              :  2000  rows  8  cols 
#>   -> target variable   :  2000  values 
#>   -> predict function  :  yhat.lm  will be used (  default  )
#>   -> predicted values  :  numerical, min =  541.1056 , mean =  1370.986 , max =  3928.189  
#>   -> residual function :  difference between y and yhat (  default  )
#>   -> residuals         :  numerical, min =  -5421.316 , mean =  -1450.523 , max =  1176.912  
#>   -> model_info        :  package stats , ver. 3.6.1 , task regression (  default  ) 
#>   A new explainer has been created!  
dragon_lm_predict4 <- variable_attribution_break_down(dragon_lm_explainer4,
                new_observation = new_dragon)
head(dragon_lm_predict4)
#>                                    contribution
#> model_4v: intercept                    1370.986
#> model_4v: scars = 0                    -397.300
#> model_4v: number_of_lost_teeth = 5     -302.277
#> model_4v: height = 80                    -9.734
#> model_4v: year_of_birth = 200            -6.639
#> model_4v: weight = 12                    -0.973
plot(dragon_lm_predict4)

# \dontrun{
library("randomForest")
dragon_rf_model4 <- randomForest(life_length ~ year_of_birth + height +
                                               weight + scars + number_of_lost_teeth,
                                 data = dragons)
dragon_rf_explainer4 <- explain(dragon_rf_model4, data = dragons, y = dragons$year_of_birth,
                                label = "model_rf")
#> Preparation of a new explainer is initiated
#>   -> model label       :  model_rf 
#>   -> data              :  2000  rows  8  cols 
#>   -> target variable   :  2000  values 
#>   -> predict function  :  yhat.randomForest  will be used (  default  )
#>   -> predicted values  :  numerical, min =  661.8135 , mean =  1370.338 , max =  3116.305  
#>   -> residual function :  difference between y and yhat (  default  )
#>   -> residuals         :  numerical, min =  -4671.021 , mean =  -1449.875 , max =  951.2935  
#>   -> model_info        :  package randomForest , ver. 4.6.14 , task regression (  default  ) 
#>   A new explainer has been created!  
dragon_rf_predict4 <- variable_attribution_break_down(dragon_rf_explainer4,
                new_observation = new_dragon)
head(dragon_rf_predict4)
#>                                    contribution
#> model_rf: intercept                    1370.338
#> model_rf: scars = 0                    -274.546
#> model_rf: number_of_lost_teeth = 5     -267.777
#> model_rf: height = 80                   177.641
#> model_rf: year_of_birth = 200             6.645
#> model_rf: weight = 12                    -1.253
plot(dragon_rf_predict4)

library("gbm")
#> Loaded gbm 2.1.5
# create a gbm model
model <- gbm(life_length ~ year_of_birth + height + weight + scars +
                           number_of_lost_teeth, data = dragons,
             distribution = "gaussian",
             n.trees = 1000,
             interaction.depth = 4,
             shrinkage = 0.01,
             n.minobsinnode = 10,
             verbose = FALSE)
 # make an explainer for the model
 explainer_gbm <- explain(model, data = dragons, predict_function =
         function(model, x) predict(model, x, n.trees = 1000))
#> Preparation of a new explainer is initiated
#>   -> model label       :  gbm  (  default  )
#>   -> data              :  2000  rows  8  cols 
#>   -> target variable   :  not specified! (  WARNING  )
#>   -> predict function  :  function(model, x) predict(model, x, n.trees = 1000) 
#>   -> predicted values  :  numerical, min =  591.5486 , mean =  1371.011 , max =  3563.598  
#>   -> residual function :  difference between y and yhat (  default  )
#>   -> model_info        :  package gbm , ver. 2.1.5 , task regression (  default  ) 
#>   A new explainer has been created!  
 # create a new observation
 exp_sgn <- variable_attribution_break_down(explainer_gbm, new_observation = new_dragon)
 head(exp_sgn)
#>                               contribution
#> gbm: intercept                    1371.011
#> gbm: scars = 0                    -386.941
#> gbm: number_of_lost_teeth = 5     -302.880
#> gbm: year_of_birth = 200            20.286
#> gbm: weight = 12                    -0.232
#> gbm: height = 80                     0.144
 plot(exp_sgn)
 # }
